newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP 96 net profit up 40 pct to 567 mln DM.
newsitem.headline: SAP 96 net profit up 40 pct to 567 mln DM.

text.p: German software developer SAP AG said on Friday its 1996 net profit rose a higher-than-expected 40 percent to 567 million marks on a sales increase of 38 percent to 3.72 billion marks.
The results, which came amid analyst concern this week that growth was slowing, were boosted by a 43 percent jump in income from ordinary activities, the company said.
"The planned currency union and (adjustments that must be made to cope with) the turn of the century have increased interest in our products worldwide," said SAP chief Dietmar Hopp.
Sales of its R/3 product rose 44 percent to 2.37 billion marks, while consulting revenue increased 47 percent to 735 million marks.
Foreign sales contributed 75 percent of sales, up from 69 percent in 1995.
SAP also said sales could rise another 25 to 30 percent in 1997.

The 1996 results surpassed the forecast SAP gave in October, when it said sales would only rise to 3.5 billion marks because of a slow third quarter. It also warned that net profit would only increase 30 percent.
Fourth-quarter sales and profit rebounded beyond SAP forecasts because of robust international growth, the company said.
Asian sales rose 67 percent to 486 million marks and American sales were up 47 percent to 1.35 billion marks. European sales rose 27 percent to 1.81 billion marks.
Fourth-quarter pre-tax profit rose 58 percent to 457 million marks, SAP said. Earnings per share for 1996 rose to 5.48 marks from four marks in 1995.
Shares of SAP soared on the news, climbing 20 marks to 239 marks after 15 minutes of pre-bourse electronic trading.

SAP signed on 1,089 new R/3 customers in 1996, bringing worldwide installations of the "client/server" software to more than 9,000. In December it began shipping R/3 Version 3.1, which includes Internet capabilities.
At the end of 1996, SAP employed 9,196 workers, up 34 percent from a year ago.
